items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Lan Nguyen, Board Vice President and Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentSUBJECT:International Baccalaureate (IB) Program Update – Lan Nguyen, Board Vice President, and Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentAt the October 20, 2009 Board Meeting under Agenda Item: 5.0 “Public Members Who Wish to address the Board of Trustees” twenty-four members of the community, students, parents, and staff spoke on behalf of the International Baccalaureate (IB) Program at Andrew Hill High School.  In addition to past successes and the positive impact of the program for the past five years, numerous concerns were expressed regarding the administrative management and oversight of the program.   Areas of concerns included:  lack of adequate funding; appropriate scheduling of classes; master scheduling errors; reductions in the coordinator’s time; lack of time to prepare the five-year study, and concerns regarding the continuance of the program.  In response to these concerns, many parents of IB students have formed a parents group in order to support the program at Andrew Hill High School.  Notwithstanding these challenging budget times, Board members and the Acting Superintendent reiterated their commitment for the program. At the request of the Board of Trustees the Board President and Acting Superintendent met with the newly formed parent group on October 27, 2009 to follow up on concerns and establish a dialog.  Before the meeting, the school administration provided an update on the IB Program and its overall impact on school. This presentation was followed by a meeting at which parents expressed concerns focusing on the continuance of the program and the level of funding provided.  Once again a commitment to the program was expressed by the district.   Parents were open to the communications and willing to work towards a common solution. Over the succeeding weeks it became apparent that an outside unbiased person was needed to help the healing process.  Recently both parties have met and are committed to work on the five year report.  While the commitment to the program and its continuance is quite clear questions remain with regards to the release time for the program coordinator.  Currently the program coordinator is released 0.2 FTE.  FISCAL IMPACT:To Be DeterminedFUNDING SOURCE:To Be DeterminedRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees request that a financial analysis of the program be made for the Board at the next upcoming Budget Study Session.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTParticipation in the Reform Immigration for America National CampaignResolution #2009-2010-30WHEREAS, the United States is a Nation of Immigrants built by immigrants, and Santa Clara County, with 38% of its population foreign-born, is the Nation’s example of how immigrant contributions can re-energize the economy and contribute to local political, social, and cultural institutions.  WHEREAS, the U.S. immigration system is broken and requires practical solutions that benefit all residents of the United States such as earned legalization, security focusing on real threats, family reunification, fair treatment of workers, immigrant integration, guaranteed due process for all, and a safety net for the most vulnerable.WHEREAS, an estimated 12 million residents of the United States are living in the shadows of society severed from life’s activities that the average American takes for granted, including authorization to work, the right to drive, access to a safety net in times of need, access to loans for higher education, the right to travel, reunification with immediate family members, the right to vote, service on juries, access to federal jobs, and many other human needs that are essential to healthy families and healthy communities.  This includes approximately 65,000 undocumented high school students, including valedictorians, top scholars, and talented athletes, who are denied the right to develop their talents and potential solely because of their legal status.  In Santa Clara County, tens of thousands of “mixed status” families with US citizen families find themselves with little opportunity and hope under our current immigration system.  WHEREAS, outdated family immigration channels keep close family members separated for decades and must be reformed to restore our commitment to promoting family unity. Those stuck in endless “backlogs” should have their admission expedited, and those admitted on work visas should be able to keep their nuclear families intact.WHEREAS, a rational and humane approach to the undocumented population should be taken by creating a rigorous registration process that leads to lawful permanent resident status and eventual citizenship. The registration program should include reasonable submission to background checks, paying taxes, and studying English. WHEREAS, the Federal government should help new immigrants learn the language and laws of the United States, ensure equal opportunity for immigrants to participate in programs and services, and support state and local governments’ efforts to help integrate these new Americans. WHEREAS, the Constitution guarantees due process for all people in this country.  Congress must restore basic civil liberties for all individuals in the United States and renew our commitment to core American values of fairness and justice.NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, the East Side Union High School District supports the reform for immigration. As a participant, East Side Union High School District pledges to take a leadership role in promoting public awareness about the urgent need for just and humane immigration reform. PASSED AND ADOPTED this 18th day of February, 2010 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTResolution #2009-2010-31In Support of theLocal Control of Local Classrooms Funding ActWHEREAS, Californians for Improved School Funding, an organization of concerned educators and citizens, is seeking signatures to qualify a statewide initiative, the Local Control of Local Classrooms Funding Act (the “Act”), for the November, 2010 ballot; and,WHEREAS, the Act would amend the California Constitution so that parcel tax measures for local school districts can be approved by 55 percent of the qualified electors; and,WHEREAS, such measures currently require a two-thirds super-majority margin for approval; and,WHEREAS, previous attempts to lower the threshold for voter approval via legislative means have not proven successful; and,WHEREAS, reductions in the state General Fund revenue have led to significantly reduced school funding; and,WHEREAS, state General Fund revenue is unstable and erratic, which results in unpredictable funding levels for school districts and county offices of education; andWHEREAS, local parcel tax revenue can provide a stable, predictable source of school revenue; and,WHEREAS, approval of the Act will empower local voters to invest in their schools based on the needs of their communities by requiring a tough, but fair, 55 percent vote to pass local parcel taxes, while protecting taxpayers and homeowners with accountability provisions that will ensure that funds generated from parcel taxes are not wasted or mismanaged; and,WHEREAS, by allowing communities to directly support their schools with local resources, this proposal enables those communities to fund important educational programs and initiatives, including:	Attracting and retaining qualified teachers;	Retaining smaller class sizes;	Supporting strong core academic programs; items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Eddie Garcia, Board President and Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentSUBJECT: Discussion and/or Action regarding Possible Parcel Tax MeasureFacing multibillion-dollar state funding cuts, school districts across California are asking residents to support local schools through parcel taxes.  A parcel is defined as any unit of land in the District that receives a separate tax bill from the Santa Clara County Assessor’s Office.  Any property that would otherwise be exempt from property taxes is also exempt from the qualified special tax.  Local parcel taxes provide one way for school districts to fund a wide array of operational and programmatic needs of an educational entity.Because of the reduction in state funding and the continuing unstable state economic climate, the East Side Union High School District is facing a huge deficit for the next school year and future years.  To assist the District in continuing its mission to provide an exemplary educational program for our students, Administration recommends that the Board of Trustees explore the feasibility of placing a parcel tax on the November 2010 ballot in an upcoming election.  Consistent with the Board President’s remarks at the State of the District address, the District would need to analyze the appropriate level of parcel tax that would generate the widest support, as well as a framework for citizen oversight.Recommendation:The Board authorize and direct administration to explore the feasibility of a parcel tax measure for the November 2010 General Election and that the administration submit its recommendation to the Board of Trustees for consideration at the March 4, 2010, Regular Board Meeting.
